Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A MHz High Energy Femtosecond Fiber Laser System for High Throughput Photonic Device Fabrication
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project will develop an integrated femtosecond high-energy fiber source for high-throughput photonics device fabrication. The final goal of the project will be a laser oscillator/amplifier that confines the pulse to the fiber throughout the generation and amplification process. This will lead to high stability, robustness, and easy integration into other systems. These characteristics will make the fiber laser system superior in terms of production throughput, size, and cost. Phase II will develop a functional prototype of the fiber laser. To demonstrate the ability of the laser to fabricate real-world devices, experiments will be carried out involving the microfabrication of glass and waveguide channels.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be a breakthrough in understanding of high-energy femtosecond fiber lasers and an unprecedented new design for laser products across a wide range of applications. The new laser product will offer a combination of high power, high repetition rate, and low cost which surpasses any existing laser on the market today. Potential markets include photonic device fabrication (e.g. for waveguides, couplers, modulators, and switches), metal processing (welding, cutting, annealing, and drilling), semiconductor and microelectronics manufacturing, general materials processing (e.g. rapid prototyping, desktop manufacturing, micromachining, and photofinishing), medical equipment, and biomedical instrumentation. In the medical area, potential applications include ophthalmology, refractive and general surgery, photocoagulation, therapeutics, imaging, and cosmetic applications. Biomedical measurements which might be affected include cytometry, DNA sequencing, laser Raman spectroscopy, spectrofluorimetry, ablation, and laser based microscopes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF funding period, we have successfully developed and commercialized high energy fs fiebr lasers by using our unique pulse shaping, spectral shaping and polarization shaping technology. 100 uJ energy level fs fiber laser has been demonstarted  in the lab. The world's most compact high energy 50 uJ fs fiber laser has been developed into a commercial product.  The technology developed through this contract has accumulated sales revenue over $1.5M. The sales revenue increased 2.5 times in 2012 compared with 2009. This provides us with a strong confidence on marketing and sales. Moreover, it proves that the technology we developed through the NSF SBIR program has a great potential for commercial applications. We would be happy to predict that the fs fiber laser has a bright future to meet growing demand for athermal material processing in both biomedical and semiconductor sectors. This is laying out a foundation for us to pursue Phase IIB matching fund for continuing our effort in developing fs fiber laser technology for commercialization and keeping our world’s leading position in high power and high energy fs fiber lasers.

A separate entity (PolarOnyx Laser, www.polaronyxlaser.com) is created to focus on ramp up of teh production in 2013, due to a solid foundation built up by this NSF SBIR contract.
